Abstract: Lily Yen, 96-year-old retired teacher and homemaker in Shanghai, recalls the terrible upheavals that overtook China in her lifetime; says young people today are materialistic and do not listen; Grace Shen, 21-year-old student, says her generation is not selfish, but wants to take advantages of the new choices they have; photo; chronology of China's history since 1911 (M)
Snippet: Lily Yen, 96-year-old retired teacher and homemaker in Shanghai, recalls the terrible upheavals that overtook China in her lifetime; says young people today are materialistic and do not listen; Grace Shen, 21-year-old student, says her generation ...
LeadParagraph: Lily Yen, born to a merchant family in Shanghai, was one of very few women in China able to attend a university in the early part of the 20th century. She volunteered to teach schoolgirls in a poor, inland rural province. War and recurrent political campaigns intruded, and Mrs. Yen's family was divided when half her relatives moved to Taiwan in 1949. Now 96 and a retired homemaker, she thinks today's young people are too self-centered and have lost the spirit of sacrifice.

Headline.Main: 'As an Archaeologist, I Have Seen Too Many Destructions'
Headline.PrintHeadline: REFLECTIONS: CHINA; 'As an Archaeologist, I Have Seen Too Many Destructions'
